properties.Status: September to May: 9am to 5pm, closed Christmas Day.
properties.Description: The award winning Visitor Centre houses a gift shop, exhibition space, function room and café. Here, you will find information about the Botanic Gardens and other Christchurch attractions through the friendly Visitor Centre team and the many maps and brochures available.

properties.Status: Late spring until the end of summer, weekdays: 10.00am to 3.00pm, weekends: 10.00am to 5.00pm.
properties.Description: A summer kiosk set near the playground and paddling pool, Duck Duck is the perfect place to grab an ice cream or cold drink.
Delighting children for years with its swings, slides and monkey bars, this playground now also features a wheelchair swing.
Situated right next to the playground and ice cream shop, it's the perfect spot for a summer splash.
Off Rolleston Avenue, this car park enters the Gardens from the Armagh Street footbridge, near the playground.
Off Riccarton Avenue, this car park borders the Hagley Park tennis courts and enters the Gardens from the West Bridge.
Situated against a backdrop of mature trees that provide shelter against wind, the Water Garden showcases a variety of species and cultivars with something to suit every home garden.

Visit Cuningham House, a traditional Winter Garden, for tropical plants from around the globe including Peperomia, Anthurium and even Banana trees. Two staircases lead to the upper floor where you can gaze over the extensive tropical plant collection from the large peripheral gallery.

Visit Gilpin House for carnivorous plants, bromelians and orchids. The connecting Garrick House fhouses a vast collection of cacti and succulents as well as  painted diorama of a desert scene that spans from South Africa to South America by Gordon Gee.
Foweraker House with an enchanting collection of alpine plants that frequently change throughout the year.

On the perimeter is Fern House which offers a peaceful oasis of native ferns including the iconic Silver Fern. A gentle stream meanders through the Fernery creating a perfect environment for moisture loving ferns such as Asplenium.
Established early in the 1900s, this garden has evolved into a fine collection of New Zealand species and is reminiscent of a temperate rainforest.
Formal in design, the Central Rose Garden sits in a sunny sheltered site and contains cultivars and hybrids of modern garden roses including bush, climbing, miniature and standard.
Many coloured dahlias add an extra attraction to the south-east fringe of the gorgeous Rose Garden, most of the collection comes from New Zealand breeders.

Developed in the early 1920s the Herbaceous Border is believed to be the longest of its kind displayed in a public garden in the Southern Hemisphere. Many colours, scents and textures layer together in contrasting shapes and heights, all showcasing perennials best suited for a Canterbury garden throughout the seasons.

This long border collection features trees and shrubs from countries such as China, Japan, Korea and Taiwan - all selected from areas with a temperate climate like Canterbury to ensure they survive. Camelia and rhododendron offer stunning flowers during the spring months.

Stunning formal bedding displays throughout spring and summer have been a staple here since the late 19th century. Annuals, biennials, shrubs and herbaceous perennials are used to provide colour, texture, form and scent.
This garden demonstrates many techniques to best utilise a small garden space including raised beds, seasonal crop rotation, companion plants and fruit trees trained in creative directions.

This hidden gem contains an extensive collection of modern, old garden and wild roses along with a vast selection of herbaceous perennials that all culminate in a beautiful display over November and December.

Named in memory of botanist Dr Leonard Cockaye in honour of his contributions to New Zealand botany, horticulture, ecology and conservation, this garden has been home to hebe, alpine plants and leptospermum beds since 1938.
Townend House is a flowering conservatory and is full of colourful conservatory flowers all year round such as Cyclamen, Begonias and Primula.

With less than 25 in the world, this peace bell was installed in 2006 in commemoration of Christchurch's status as a peace city. Gifted by The World Peace Bell Association in Tokyo, the bell is made of coins and medals from around the world and symbolises the world being one.

Set in the picturesque Armstrong Lawn, the Peacock Fountain was purchased from the famous Coalbrookdale Foundry in Shropshire, England and erected in 1911. Dismantled in 1949, public support called for its restoration and it was recommissioned in 1996. This iconic fountain has long been a contentious piece in the art world, its colours and form often criticised, but it is nonetheless seen by many Cantabrians as an integral part of the Botanic Gardens.

Erected in 1926 to commemorate bandsmen who died in the First World War, the Rotunda acts as a venue for a wide range of musical acts. During spring, thousands of daffodils flower around it creating a particularly pleasant and peaceful atmosphere.
